newsitem.title: AUSTRIA: Austria's Lauda sees steady '96 profit.
newsitem.headline: Austria's Lauda sees steady '96 profit.

text.p: Austrian airline Lauda Air said on Monday it expected 1995/96 full-year earnings to be on par with last year's results.
Lauda reported net profit of 47.1 million schillings on turnover of 2.67 billion for the year to October 31, 1995.
Former Formula One racing champion and chief executive Niki Lauda predicted profit after tax this year would be between 40 and 50 million schillings on turnover of about three billion.
"We will also pay the same dividend," he added. Last year the company paid a dividend of four schillings on common stock, while holders of participation certificates received eight schillings.
Lauda said the first half had been typically poor during the winter season, but the summer had been profitable.
The company had increased its ratio of scheduled flights to charter traffic to 60:40 compared with 35:65 two years ago.
But relations with arch rival Austrian Air had deteriorated, Lauda said. A cooperation deal struck by the two airlines in February had come to nothing, he added.

"There have not yet been any concrete attacks, but we may also consider flying to New York," said Lauda. A deal with Lufthansa-partner United Airlines would be conceivable as Lufthansa holds a 39.7 percent share in Lauda.
Lauda also indicated he was eyeing a foray into eastern Europe -- until now the domain of state-controlled Austrian Air.
